project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: Archaeogenetic study analysing genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning 5400-2400 BC. Investigates genetic and cultural contact between Copper Age farming groups and Eneolithic steppe-associated groups during the critical period between two major genetic turnover events in prehistoric western Eurasia.

evidence.content: 135 ancient individuals analysed from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and northwestern Black Sea region
evidence.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

evidence.content: Individuals span time period covering critical interval between two genetic turnover events
evidence.verbatim_quote: spanning this critical time period

evidence.content: Genome-wide data obtained from ancient individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals

evidence.content: Genetic continuity observed between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region
evidence.verbatim_quote: we observe genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region

evidence.content: From around 4500 BC on, groups from northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: from around 4500 bc on, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and those from the forest/steppe zones

evidence.content: Varna necropolis dated to 4600-4300 BC on Black Sea coast
evidence.verbatim_quote: The discovery of the necropolis of Varna (4600–4300 bc) on the Black Sea coast

evidence.content: Many tell settlements emerged during Copper Age (4900-3800 BC) in SEE
evidence.verbatim_quote: The many tell settlements that emerged during the Copper Age (CA, 4900–3800 bc) in SEE

evidence.content: Major tell sites Mound Măgura Gorgana (Pietrele, Gumelniţa culture) and Tell Yunatsite (Karanovo culture) occupied for several centuries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Mound Măgura Gorgana near Pietrele on the Lower Danube in Romania, associated with the Gumelniţa culture and Tell Yunatsite in Bulgaria, associated with the Karanovo culture (Fig. 1 and Extended Data Fig. 1), which were occupied for several centuries

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Three evidence items describing tell sites all support only C019. Never assessed independently. Consolidated into single statement about tell settlement pattern.

evidence.verbatim_quote: From around 4600 bc, the similarity and continuous development of material culture and exchange of raw materials in the so-called Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex

evidence.content: Roughly simultaneous abandonment of numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 BC
evidence.verbatim_quote: the roughly simultaneous abandonment of the numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 bc

evidence.content: Copper was mined, smelted and used to make axes, jewellery and small tools during fifth/fourth millennia BC
evidence.verbatim_quote: copper was mined, smelted and used to make axes, jewellery and small tools

evidence.content: Tell settlements involved in proto-industrial exploitation of copper, gold and salt
evidence.verbatim_quote: involved in the proto-industrial exploitation of copper13, gold and salt

evidence.content: Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex spans southern Romania (Gumelniţa), northern Bulgaria (Kodžadermen) and Thrace (Karanovo)
evidence.verbatim_quote: the so-called Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex across southern Romania (Gumelniţa), northern Bulgaria (Kodžadermen) and Thrace (Karanovo)

evidence.verbatim_quote: exchange of raw materials in the so-called Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex

evidence.content: Abandonment circumstances might have involved depletion of resources and deterioration of soils
evidence.verbatim_quote: The underlying circumstances are unclear and might have involved the depletion of resources, the deterioration of soils

evidence.content: PIE039 from Pietrele falls in expected range of SEE Neolithic individuals and shares affinities according to PCA and outgroup f3 statistics
evidence.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both support only C025 and describe same genetic similarity using different statistical methods (PCA + f3). Consolidated into single compound evidence preserving both methods.

evidence.content: Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N most symmetrically related to PIE039 (|Z| ≤ 1), combined into SEE 1 group for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1) and thus combined them into local group SEE 1, which could be used as a single source for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Two sequential findings (symmetry test → grouping decision) form single analytical procedure. Never assessed independently.

evidence.content: SEE CA individuals from Yunatsite, Varna, Pietrele, and Petko Karavelovo form tight cluster overlapping with Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE
evidence.verbatim_quote: In PCA space, the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE29

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Clustering and overlap are single observation in PCA space, artificially split in Pass 1.

evidence.content: Outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout CA in this region
evidence.verbatim_quote: Moreover, outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

evidence.content: All SEE CA groups slightly shifted towards EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals.

evidence.content: Distal qpAdm modelling confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry.

evidence.content: Ancestry composition already present during Neolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: This ancestry composition is already present during the Neolithic29

evidence.content: f4 test shows Neolithic groups form clade with SEE CA with respect to HG groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: and confirmed by the test f4 (test, CA; HGs, Mbuti) in which Neolithic groups form a clade with SEE CA with respect to HG groups

evidence.content: All SEE CA groups could be modelled as single-source model using locally preceding Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale.

evidence.content: Outlier individual PIE060 shifted further towards WHG/EHG cluster in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry

evidence.content: f4 statistics confirmed excess WHG/EHG ancestry in PIE060 (|Z| ≥ 3)
evidence.verbatim_quote: which could be confirmed by f4 statistics of the form f4(SEE N, PIE060; HGs, Mbuti) ((|Z| ≥ 3); Supplementary Table F).

evidence.content: qpAdm supports two-way model for PIE060 with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies.

evidence.content: DATES admixture estimate for PIE060 is 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), corresponding to around 81–832 years before mean 14C date
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using DATES33 to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), which corresponds to around 81–832 years before the mean 14C date of PIE060, when a generation time of 28 years is assumed34.

evidence.content: Flat decay curve for PIE060 supports interpretation of recent admixture date
evidence.verbatim_quote: A flat decay curve (Extended Data Fig. 3a) supports the interpretation of a recent admixture date

evidence.content: Individuals with similarly high HG ancestry reported from nearby Malak Preslavets (around 70 km) and Dzhulyunitsa (around 140 km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Indeed, individuals with similarly high amounts of HG ancestry have been reported from nearby sites in Malak Preslavets (around 70 km) and Dzhulyunitsa (around 140 km)29.

evidence.content: Y-chromosomal and mtDNA lineages common in nearly all Neolithic and CA groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: In line with the autosomal data, the Y-chromosomal and mitochondrial DNA lineages are common in nearly all Neolithic and CA groups studied until now

evidence.content: Several males carry typical Mesolithic Y lineages (C1a and I2a), including PIE060
evidence.verbatim_quote: albeit with several males also carrying typical Mesolithic (C1a and I2a) Y lineages35, including individual PIE060

evidence.content: Seven different main Y lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88)

evidence.content: Six Y lineages among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88)

evidence.content: Four Y lineages among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)
evidence.verbatim_quote: and four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)

evidence.content: Only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships detected in total across SEE CA sites using READ
evidence.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

evidence.content: No evidence for between-site links up to fourth to fifth degree in IBD analysis
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree

evidence.verbatim_quote: and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

evidence.verbatim_quote: Integrating the normalized sum and number of shared blocks we find higher background relatedness at the intrasite level at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele

evidence.content: ROH analysis using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes, consistent with previous observation across early farming societies

evidence.verbatim_quote: The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

evidence.verbatim_quote: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect43, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites44,45 and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates.

evidence.content: Offset of around 500 years would still date most Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to fourth millennium BC
evidence.verbatim_quote: However, accounting for this possibility, an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc

evidence.verbatim_quote: conditioning on Steppe Eneolithic (Extended Data Fig. 6b), we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.content: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as three-way mixture in proximal qpAdm

evidence.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV)52, while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica

consolidation_metadata.rationale: VAR021 additional pathogen is detail of overall screening results, not independent finding.

evidence.verbatim_quote: Of the 135 individuals reported in this study we obtained new direct 14C dates for 113 individuals. Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

implicit_arguments.content: Genetic data reliably indicates actual historical admixture events and cultural contact rather than methodological artifacts or alternative demographic processes
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: indicating genetic and cultural contact; carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries
implicit_arguments.rationale: Study assumes genetic mixing patterns directly reflect historical processes (gene flow, cultural interaction) rather than arising from sampling artifacts, analytical choices, or alternative demographic scenarios (structure, drift). This bridges statistical observation (ancestry components, admixture) to historical interpretation (actual contact, population mixing) without explicit justification of inferential framework.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both address reliability of genetic data for inferring historical processes. IA001 focused on cultural contact inference, IA002 on admixture reality. These are facets of same core assumption about genetic data's interpretive power.

implicit_arguments.content: Transfer of innovations requires direct contact between cultural groups
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders
implicit_arguments.rationale: Implicitly assumes innovations were transferred through direct contact rather than independent invention, diffusion through intermediaries, or other mechanisms

implicit_arguments.content: Material wealth and gold deposits directly indicate levels of social stratification in past societies
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: with large quantities of gold and other symbols of power and wealth suggesting unprecedented levels of social stratification
implicit_arguments.rationale: The claim assumes that material markers of wealth in burials directly reflect social hierarchy levels, rather than potentially representing other cultural meanings (ritual significance, trading networks, craft specialisation). The leap from 'gold in graves' to 'unprecedented social stratification' bridges multiple unstated assumptions about burial practices, wealth display, and social structure.

implicit_arguments.content: Simultaneous abandonment of geographically dispersed sites requires unified causal explanation
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Consequently, the roughly simultaneous abandonment of the numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 bc appears enigmatic
implicit_arguments.rationale: The use of 'consequently' and characterisation as 'enigmatic' implies that synchronous abandonment across multiple sites demands a single shared cause (environmental, social, or political). This bridges from observation (sites abandoned around same time) to assessment (puzzling/requiring explanation) without explicitly stating why simultaneity necessitates unified causation rather than coincidence or loosely connected regional factors.

implicit_arguments.content: PCA clustering and genetic outlier patterns directly reflect population histories rather than methodological artifacts or alternative demographic scenarios
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: form a tight cluster; came from a community outside Pietrele with recent contact with HGs
implicit_arguments.rationale: Study interprets PCA clusters as reflecting genetic homogeneity and outliers as indicating external origins. This assumes statistical patterns directly map to demographic realities (clustering→homogeneity, outlier→migration) without explicitly addressing whether patterns could reflect sampling, preservation, analytical choices, or within-population admixture rather than migration.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both address assumptions about interpreting genetic patterns (clustering, outliers) as demographic signals. Facets of same core assumption about pattern-to-process inference.

implicit_arguments.content: Limited genetic relatedness between sites indicates separate mating networks despite cultural connectivity
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree
implicit_arguments.rationale: The interpretation that minimal IBD sharing indicates separate communities assumes that absence of detected relatedness reflects biological reality rather than methodological limitations (sampling intensity, IBD detection thresholds, temporal resolution). Given earlier claims of 'transregional connectedness' (C021) based on material culture, the genetic isolation requires bridging argument about how populations maintained cultural connections while limiting genetic exchange.

implicit_arguments.content: Genetic clines in PCA space directly reflect biological admixture processes rather than statistical artifacts
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals
implicit_arguments.rationale: The interpretation of a cline as indicating 'possible admixture' assumes that intermediate PCA positions reflect biological mixing. This bridges from statistical pattern (cline in PC space) to biological process (admixture) without explicitly addressing alternative explanations such as shared ancestral structure, differential drift, or methodological effects of projecting ancient samples onto modern PCA axes.

implicit_arguments.content: Genetic patterns align with and validate archaeological interpretations of cultural contact
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: as in line with cultural interactions described in the archaeological record
implicit_arguments.rationale: The phrase 'in line with' implies mutual validation between genetic and archaeological evidence, assuming both datasets independently capture the same historical processes. This bridges genetic admixture patterns to cultural interactions without explicitly stating the relationship between biological gene flow and cultural exchange (which may be correlated but not identical).

implicit_arguments.content: Absence of temporal correlation in genetic variation indicates ongoing contact rather than single admixture event
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none
implicit_arguments.rationale: The lack of temporal trend is presented as meaningful (tested explicitly), implying it informs our understanding of the contact process. This assumes that constant genetic variation across time reflects sustained admixture rather than alternative scenarios (rapid mixing followed by stasis, sampling gaps masking trends, or insufficient statistical power). The bridging assumption is that temporal patterns in genetic data directly reflect demographic process dynamics.

implicit_arguments.content: Y-chromosome haplogroups reliably track population ancestry and historical connections
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy
implicit_arguments.rationale: The interpretation of Y-chromosome lineages as 'suggestive of HG legacy' or 'characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya' assumes uniparental markers reliably indicate population history. This bridges from observing specific haplogroups to inferring ancestry sources, assuming limited male-mediated gene flow, no lineage extinction/drift in source populations, and that haplogroup geography reflects ancient rather than more recent distributions.

implicit_arguments.content: Two distinct EBA genetic clusters reflect separate migration events or populations
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry
implicit_arguments.rationale: The description of 'two contrasting clusters' and their interpretation as representing different ancestries (farmer-like vs steppe-like) assumes genetic clustering reflects distinct demographic histories. This bridges from statistical clustering to demographic interpretation without explicitly addressing whether clusters represent separate migration streams, temporal layering, sampling from distinct social groups within mixed populations, or continuous variation artificially divided by analytical methods.

implicit_arguments.content: Genetic homogeneity necessarily indicates absence of internal conflicts
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: given the near-identical genetic ancestry profiles of SEE CA groups, we caution that genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts, causing the replacement of one CA group by another
implicit_arguments.rationale: The authors explicitly acknowledge this limitation, noting that genetic similarity could mask internal conflicts if one CA group replaced another with similar ancestry. This implicit argument recognizes that genetic data cannot distinguish all forms of social/political change - replacement by genetically similar groups would be invisible to archaeogenetic analysis.

implicit_arguments.content: Genetic variation patterns directly reflect historical cultural and demographic processes
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Moreover, variable cultural influences attested by the archaeological record40,41,53 are also traceable genetically
implicit_arguments.rationale: The claim that cultural influences are 'traceable genetically' assumes correspondence between cultural variation (from archaeology) and genetic variation. This bridges two independent data types assuming they track the same underlying historical processes, without explicit discussion of scenarios where cultural and biological exchange might be decoupled (e.g., cultural diffusion without migration, or migration with cultural assimilation).

implicit_arguments.content: Exchange networks facilitated by contact zones directly caused development of pastoralism
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction, which then led to the establishment of fully developed pastoralism
implicit_arguments.rationale: The causal language ('which then led to') implies exchange through contact zones was necessary/sufficient for pastoralist development. This bridges from observing contact (genetic admixture) to technological/economic causation without explicitly addressing alternative scenarios (independent pastoralist development, earlier but archaeologically invisible exchange, or different causal mechanisms).

implicit_arguments.content: Mosaic of ancestries contradicts model of genetically uniform prehistoric Europe
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: and a mosaic of ancestries rather than a genetically uniform CA and EBA Europe
implicit_arguments.rationale: The phrase 'rather than' sets up an implicit alternative model being rejected. This bridges from specific observations (HG ancestry resurgence, remnant HG groups) to a broader claim about European population structure. The implicit argument assumes previous models proposed uniformity, and that the observed variation is inconsistent with such models, without explicitly defining what 'genetically uniform' would mean or citing the models being rejected.

implicit_arguments.content: Consistency between radiocarbon dates and archaeological chronology validates both dating methods
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: All 14C dates in this study are consistent with the archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods
implicit_arguments.rationale: The statement of consistency is presented as validation, implicitly arguing that agreement between independent dating methods (radiometric vs relative/contextual) strengthens confidence in both. This assumes that consistency indicates accuracy rather than potentially reflecting systematic biases affecting both methods similarly, or that archaeological chronology is sufficiently well-established to serve as validation standard.

implicit_arguments.content: Clean room facilities and dedicated ancient DNA laboratories ensure contamination-free results
implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities
implicit_arguments.rationale: Mentioning clean room facilities implicitly argues these precautions ensure authentic ancient DNA recovery rather than modern contamination. This bridges from procedural safeguards to result authenticity, assuming facility specifications are sufficient to prevent contamination and that other quality controls (damage patterns, contamination estimates) support this interpretation.

methods.trigger_text: Fig. 1b; Fig. 2; Fig. 3; Extended Data Fig.
methods.inference_reasoning: Extensive figures presented (PCA plots, geographic maps, admixture bar plots) with no documentation of visualization software, parameter choices, or graphic design decisions. These visualization choices affect interpretation.

protocols.content: Obtain archaeological permissions from excavators, archaeologists, curators and museum directors
protocols.verbatim_quote: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study

protocols.content: Select samples from 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth across target sites and time periods
protocols.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

protocols.content: Sample petrous bones using minimal invasive method; for teeth separate crown from root and drill out pulp chamber
protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method61 and, for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out62

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Two sampling procedures for different tissue types, always assessed as complete sampling protocol.

protocols.content: Extract DNA using modified protocol from refs 63,64 in dedicated clean room facilities
protocols.verbatim_quote: Ancient DNA work was carried out in dedicated clean room facilities of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology (MPI-EVA), Leipzig and Jena, Germany... DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64

protocols.content: Build double-stranded libraries using partial UDG-half treatment
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment65

protocols.content: Perform accelerated mass spectrometry radiocarbon dating at Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie
protocols.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

protocols.content: Calibrate radiocarbon dates using IntCal20 database and OxCal v.4.4.2
protocols.verbatim_quote: All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2

protocols.content: Enrich libraries above 0.1% endogenous threshold using 1.24M SNP in-solution capture
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture)31

protocols.content: Project ancient samples onto modern PCA axes and map genetic affinities geographically
protocols.verbatim_quote: In PCA space... outgroup f3 statistics when mapped geographically (Fig. 2)

consolidation_metadata.rationale: PCA projection and geographic mapping are two visualization approaches for same genetic affinity data.

protocols.content: Calculate f-statistics: outgroup f3(ancient1, ancient2; Mbuti) for shared drift and f4(test, target; reference, Mbuti) for differential ancestry with |Z| ≥ 3 significance threshold
protocols.verbatim_quote: outgroup f3 statistics... using f4-symmetry statistics... significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

consolidation_metadata.rationale: f3 and f4 are related f-statistics differing in test structure but using same computational framework. Assessed as integrated statistical toolkit.

protocols.content: Perform proximal qpAdm modelling using locally preceding groups as sources
protocols.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model

protocols.content: Perform distal qpAdm modelling using cornerstone populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG, CHG)
protocols.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry

protocols.content: Use DATES software with 28-year generation time assumption to estimate admixture timing
protocols.verbatim_quote: Using DATES33 to determine the time of admixture... when a generation time of 28 years is assumed34

protocols.content: Determine Y-chromosome and mitochondrial DNA haplogroups from sequence data
protocols.verbatim_quote: [Implied from haplogroup results - specific calling procedure from Extended Data Fig. 3b]

protocols.content: Use READ software to detect genetic relatedness up to fifth degree
protocols.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ

protocols.content: Use hapROH software to analyze runs of homozygosity for parental relatedness inference
protocols.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH

protocols.content: Calculate Spearman correlation coefficient between PC2 position and calibrated 14C dates
protocols.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates... (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

protocols.content: Select Turkey_N, WHG, EHG/WSHG, and CHG as reference cornerstone populations
protocols.verbatim_quote: four Holocene 'cornerstone' populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG/WSHG and CHG)

protocols.content: Screen teeth samples systematically for ancient pathogens
protocols.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens

protocols.content: Attempt automated single-stranded non-UDG library protocol for low-yield samples
protocols.verbatim_quote: For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries66,67

protocols.content: Double-index all libraries with unique pair of indices
protocols.verbatim_quote: All libraries were double-indexed with a unique pair of indices68

protocols.content: Screen libraries via shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on Illumina HiSeq4000/NextSeq500
protocols.verbatim_quote: First, all indexed libraries were screened by means of shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on an Illumina HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 sequencing platform using a single end (1 × 75 base pair (bp) reads) kit

protocols.content: Assess endogenous DNA content and damage profiles from screening data
protocols.verbatim_quote: followed by an assessment of human DNA content and DNA damage profiles (initial quality criteria)

protocols.content: Apply 0.1% endogenous DNA threshold for enrichment eligibility
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched

protocols.content: Combine Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N into local group SEE 1 based on symmetry test (|Z| ≤ 1)
protocols.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1) and thus combined them into local group SEE 1

protocols.content: Identify IBD blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of fifth to seventh degree relationships
protocols.verbatim_quote: only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

protocols.content: Calculate normalized sum and number of shared IBD blocks for background relatedness assessment
protocols.verbatim_quote: Integrating the normalized sum and number of shared blocks we find higher background relatedness at the intrasite level

protocols.content: Select reference populations: present-day West Eurasians for PCA projection and Mbuti as outgroup for f-statistics
protocols.trigger_text: present-day West Eurasian populations; Mbuti; outgroup
protocols.inference_reasoning: Reference population choices (modern panel for PCA, African outgroup for f-stats) are undocumented but shape all genetic affinity interpretations. Selection criteria and population composition not specified.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both are reference population selection decisions for different analyses. Assessed together as reference framework choices.

protocols.content: Source population selection for qpAdm models
protocols.trigger_text: SEE N; VAR_CA; Ukraine Trypillia; Iron Gates HG; KO1
protocols.inference_reasoning: qpAdm requires selecting specific source populations for modeling, but criteria for source selection (geographic proximity, temporal overlap, genetic distinctiveness?) not documented. Different sources used for different targets without documented rationale.

protocols.content: SNP filtering and imputation for genetic analyses
protocols.inference_reasoning: Capture targets 1.24M SNPs but actual coverage varies per sample. Missing data handling (e.g., missingness thresholds, imputation, pseudo-haploid calling) not documented despite being standard for ancient DNA.

protocols.content: Contamination estimation and filtering procedure
protocols.inference_reasoning: Damage profiles mentioned as quality criterion suggesting contamination estimation (modern DNA has low damage), but method for contamination estimation (X-chromosome, autosomal methods) and acceptable threshold not documented.

protocols.content: Sample duplication and read merging procedures
protocols.inference_reasoning: Libraries screened then enriched and re-sequenced, implying data merging from multiple sequencing runs, but deduplication strategy and read merging procedures not documented.

protocols.content: Significance threshold application for statistical tests
protocols.inference_reasoning: Uses |Z| ≥ 3 for f-statistics and various P-value thresholds, but rationale for threshold choices and multiple testing correction (if any) not documented. Standard practice vs study-specific choice unclear.

protocols.content: Temporal binning and periodization for chronological grouping
protocols.trigger_text: Neolithic; Copper Age; Eneolithic; Early Bronze Age
protocols.inference_reasoning: Individuals assigned to periods (Neolithic, CA, Eneolithic, EBA) implying temporal grouping rules, but date boundaries and criteria for period assignment (radiocarbon date, archaeological context, both?) not documented.

protocols.content: Geographic coordinate mapping and spatial analysis parameters
protocols.inference_reasoning: Geographic mapping of genetic affinities presented but coordinate system, interpolation method, and spatial parameters not documented.
